channel.title: On My Wavelength
channel.description: This is an aggregated RSS feed of all my publications.

item.title: Not All Men, But Always a Man
item.description: Why more abusers are men than any other demographic.

item.title: You Don't Come Closer
item.description: It's a late November night at a cafe when the past decides to visit you. For your luck or otherwise, there is someone to listen to you—someone that actually cares.

item.title: Gen-AI is just a fancy bootlicker
item.description: Making a set of equations write poetry is not just lazy, it's a betrayal to what human creativity is.

item.title: The Nights Were Young
item.description: Aragalaya ("Struggle") was one of the most pivotal events I have ever witnessed and taken part in. It was an experience of both pride and fear alike. Ousting a family of war criminals and thieves, along with the toxic political world they built, cost more than just sweat and tears.

item.title: I See Only You
item.description: Grief and guilt breaks the soul of all affected by it. When the narrator accidentally kills their partner, the guilt of it consumes them into an irreversible spiral.

item.title: Are Girl-Children Immoral and Dangerous Seductresses in Lolita?
item.description: In Nabokov’s Lolita, readers are presented with Humbert Humbert, who grooms and eventually rapes Dolores Haze, his “Lolita”. Despite his regret of the “foul lust [he] had inflicted upon [her],” and Dr. John Ray’s denouncement of Humbert as “horrible [and] abject,” in the preface, the social perception of Dolores and the “girl-children” is far from being absolved.

item.title: Implications of Buddhism on Political Systems
item.description: Buddhism, the state religion of Sri Lanka, has remained entangled in all lives and institutions of Sri Lanka. Historically, royal patronage and religious loyalty have elevated Buddhism to a state of authority.

item.title: The Authorial God Hypothesis
item.description: God—in many belief systems and prominently, the Abrahamic tradition—is an omnipotent, omniscient, omnipresent, omnibenevolent, and perfect being. These faiths and beliefs also credit God for creating the universe and its inhabitants: us.

item.title: Paint My Skies With Yellow Sparks
item.description: As someone who has lived through the end of a civil war, yet at great relative safety, it was very easy to be disillusioned. The horror of war is not a myth, but many wish it was and many think it is.

item.title: Maybe the Gods are Playing Cricket
item.description: As a child, I liked to imagine the scary and loud thunderstorms were just cricket matches in heaven. There was a sense of comfort in it, but also felt gross to be under the rain.

item.title: The Crying Maiden
item.description: When Prof. Senavitharana is gifted a mysterious painting of a crying maiden, he does not believe the strange tale behind it. But when the tale comes alive to haunt him, he soon realises his mistake.

item.title: 50 Shades of Gender: Gender Complexity and a Post-Gender Society
item.description: For much of recorded history, gender and sex were used interchangeably: male meant XY chromosomes and masculinity, and female meant XX chromosomes and femininity. However, modern gender has evolved into a broader and more nuanced spectrum.

item.title: Maybe in a Few Years
item.description: Do ever think of your friends two minutes to midnight and only feel unreserved love for those idiots? Yeah, me too. This is for my goof balls (they'll hate me for calling them that).

item.title: Laboratory life: my work experience week at BGS
item.description: My week began with a welcome tour of the research facilities at BGS and, more specifically, the geochemistry laboratories. The team provided an introduction to the field of mass spectrometry and the use of isotopes in archaeological research.

item.title: why it matters to remember
item.description: cecil richard’s under a star called sun is a reader-led short story about a narrator where “the trajectory of [his] ship is unchanging.” he (i like to see myself on the ship; you may too) recalls that coffee “never tastes as good as the ones you get from the cafes back home”.

item.title: He Fought for You
item.description: Mahmoud Darwish once wrote, "The wars will end and the leaders will shake hands, [...] I do not know who sold the homeland but I know who paid the price." This is for all those who paid the price.

item.title: Collided Galaxies
item.description: Grief is often raw and remains a sad and tender reminder of the past. It is a soft ache that refuses to go away. Maybe in this cosmic dance, you may see someone else's stars embedded in your galaxy.

item.title: A Summer Night Under the Moon
item.description: The stars hide a grand secret we are too stupid to know. But does it ever matter? Does anything hold meaning when you're drunk with love and run over by her beauty?

item.title: #2: The Limit of Opinion Entitlement
item.description: People are entitled to their opinions, but general consensus agree that there is a limit to it. However, what is this limit? Where does it begin, and where does it end? Who decides the limits?

item.title: #1: Social Media and the Whole Thing
item.description: What does it take to be an influencer? And what role does the audience actually play within this system? Find out with us!

item.title: Cost of Living and University Choices
item.description: This is a report I co-authored with Adam Runacres, Freya Neason, and Ismail Choudhury for The Access Project. We conducted introductory research on the relationship between the university choices of students and the economic background.

item.title: Masked Figures
item.description: The pandemic, and the lonliness that stemmed from it, left a large imprint on all of us that survived it. This is for the horrors we all battled with ourselves, and fear during then.

item.title: How to make a Debating Motion?
item.description: So, what is a motion? Basically, it is the topic which the debate is about. There are two sides which would be arguing this (although there could be four teams, sometimes).

item.title: A Name I Didn't Think Of
item.description: This is a story of a slow-burn on fast-forward. He is a Physicist and she is a Philosopher, and they both end up finding that there's more that attracts than Gravity.

item.title: Death's Fear
item.description: Death is though to be the ultimate villain, the ghost that haunts over our shoulders. This is how death sees some people, and it's never about our pretty little lives.
